docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.

  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
Components are reusable parts of UI that you can put together to make a complete UI.

Here you'll find a list of every single component in InnerComponents. Each component has 2 parts:

  • API - This goes into the properties for a component and how you can configure them
  • Guidelines - Specfic guidelines on how to use a component correctly.

If you are here just for the component guidelines, we recomend also reading through the Guidlines first to get a basic understanding of the core design rules.

docs.title: Guidlines
docs.text:
Welcome to the component guidelines! Here you will find guides on what To and not to do when using the Inner Design language!

If you are looking for the guidelines on a specific component, look bellow for some commonly accessed ones:

docs.title: Foundations
docs.text: Every good design language has a strong foundation of the system. This section of articles details fundamentally how systems work, with what you can and can't do.

docs.title: Accessibility
docs.text:
Products shouldn't be restricted to people with disabilities. Thats why Inner Design strives on making sure all users are able to use the system.

It is highly recomended to implement all princibles to maximize accessibility.

docs.title: Animation
docs.text:
Some users are sensitive to motion/animation, whether for accessibility reasons, or personal prefrence.

  • There should always be an option to turn of animations.
  • Your App should remain fully functional with disabled animations.

docs.title: Contrast
docs.text:
Text and interactive elements must maintain sufficient contrast against their background.

  • Text should be clearly readable in both light and dark modes.
  • Disabled elements should still be legible.

Do

The text is easy to read, and contrasts the background well.

Don't

The text is hard to read, and doesnt contrast the background well.

docs.title: Color blindness
docs.text:
Design with color blindness in mind. When choosing colors:

  • Differences should rely on value, not just hue.
  • Important information should never be communicated using only color.

docs.title: Input
docs.text:
Users shouldn't be required to perform precise or fast inputs.

  • Timed-based actions should have a wide response window. Idealy around 5-10 seconds.
  • Avoid actions like double-clicks.

Do

Click/Tap targets should be larger then they appear visually.

docs.title: Animation
docs.text: Animation is the process of adding motion to a design to provide feedback. In Inner Design Animation is used to create a more intuitive user experince. Animations follow the following rules:

docs.title: Everything doesnt need animation
docs.text:
Its better to keep your designs simple and static.

  • Animate in response to a users action.

docs.title: Quick and simple
docs.text:
Animations should be fast and straightforward rather than complicated.

  • Animations shouldn't slow down the overall use of an app.

docs.title: Non-Frame rate dependent
docs.text: Animations must complete in the same amount of time for all users, regardless of frame rate.

docs.title: Color
docs.text: Color exists to communicate meaning of elements while letting the personality of your app shine. In Inner Design color is used to comunicate state, hierarchy and user feedback.

docs.title: Color should exist for a reason
docs.text:
Color should only be used to communicate meaning. Color should not be used only for decoritive purposes.

Do

Use color to indicate state, importance, or user feedback.

Don't

Don't add color just to make a layout feel less empty or more "interesting".

Tip

If removing the color doesn't change meaning, it likely doesn't belong.

docs.title: Palettes
docs.text: In Inner Design You define colors to use through a color palette. Colors should not differ from this palette unless absoultely necessary for the functionality of your app.

docs.title: Accent Color
docs.text:
When defining a color pallete most colors should be pretty much colorless, this is to put emphasis on your apps Accent.

Don't

Don't overuse the accent color. It should be used sparingly to put emphasis on important elements.

docs.title: Feedback
docs.text:
Change the color of an element, or use the accent color to give feedback to the users current action.

  • Feedback should never rely on color alone.

docs.title: Gradients
docs.text:
Gradients shouldn't be used in most situations, flat colors will always do.

Don't

Gradients shouldn't be used directly on static elements like frames.

docs.title: Layout
docs.text: Layout is how elements are arranged to create hierarchy and flow. In Inner Design, layout rules exist to make interfaces easy to understand at a glance.

docs.title: Hierarchy
docs.text:
What is Hierarchy?

Hierarchy is a mental diagram of importance, from most to least important.

In design, it’s used to communicate what the user should notice first, second, and last in an interface.

The Layout of elements should clearly communicate what is and isnt important.

Do

Use size, spacing, and placement to show importance.

Primary actions and content should naturally draw the eye first.

Don't

Don't give everything equal visual weight.

When everything looks just as important, it can confuse the user, making your designs no longer "Invisible".

docs.title: Spacing / Padding
docs.text: Spacing is used to group related elements and separate unrelated ones.

docs.title: Shapes and Icons
docs.text: In Inner Design, shapes and icons always follow the following rules:

docs.title: Rounding
docs.text: All shapes are rounded, there are never hard corners. A minimum of 6 pixels corner radius is used for All components.

docs.title: No Stroke
docs.text: Shapes DO NOT have stroke around them. They always are one color.

docs.title: Icons
docs.text: Icons are part of the Lucide Icon pack. For the case of custom icons, they should always follow the lucide style guide.

docs.title: No Filled Icons
docs.text: This is to emphasize Lucide's rule. There are no filled icons in Inner Design!

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text:
Welecome to the InnerComponents Tutorials! These Guides will help you understand how to use the library.

Keep in mind!

Fusion is in a pre-release state. Because of this, versions of InnerComponents will always stay up to date with the newest Fusion version. Whenever a newer version of Fusion comes out, the next verion of InnerComponents will then adopt that version.

Thank you for using InnerComponents!

docs.title: Previous Knowledge
docs.text:
It is assumed you know the following subjects.

  • Understanding of the Luau language.
  • Understanding of the Fusion UI library.

docs.title: Get Started
docs.text:
The following Tutorials will teach you how to fundamently use InnerComponents. It will teach you how to use the most fundamental of Components, and interact with the API.

Note

These tutorials don't cover everything! It is recomended to check both the API and Guidelines for more extensive guides on usage on specific components!
